Observations: Software Working through Doc
Does the website and documentation provide a clear, high-level overview of your software?
Does the website and documentation clearly describe the type of user who should use your software?
Do this project publish case studies to show how your software has been used by yourself and others?
Project and Software's Uniquness
Is the name of the project/software unique?
Comments: No other extension is available on the chrome web store with the exact same name

Observations: Is the project/software name free from trademark violations?
Avaibility of Software
Is this software available as a package that can be deployed without building it?
Comments: We need to just add the extension in chrome

Observations: Is your software available for free?
Comments: It is open source with MIT Licence

Observations: Is your source code publicly available to download, either as a downloadable bundle or via access to a source code repository?

Is your software hosted in an established, third-party repository likeGitHub (https://github.com), BitBucket (https://bitbucket.org),LaunchPad (https://launchpad.net) orSourceForge (https://sourceforge.net)?
Software's documentation
Is the documentation clearly available on your website or within your software?
Does the documentation include a "quick start" guide, that provides a short overview of how to use your software with some basic examples of use?
Comments: Here is the link to the Demo. https://github.com/shyamal31/units_converter_extension#popup-features-for-the-user

Observations: If the documentation is extensive, does this provide clear, step-by-step instructions on how to deploy and use the software?
Does it provide a comprehensive guide to all the software’s commands, functions and options?
Comments: Home page of the repository covers all the functions. Also, appropriate documentation is provided with corresponding files.

Observations: Does it provide troubleshooting information that describes the symptoms and step-by-step solutions for problems and error messages?
Comments: Installation is straightforward and there is no scope for errors. Nevertheless, an email has been provided so that users can contact with their queries.

Observations: If the software can be used as a library, package or service by other software, do it provide comprehensive API documentation?
Is documentation stored under revision control with the source code?
Does the software publish release history e.g. release data, version numbers, key features of each release etc. on their web site or in your documentation?
Comments: This is the version 3 of the software. Version 2 was launched by the team before us. https://zenodo.org/records/10211931

Observations: Software User Support
Does this software describe how a user can get help with using your software?
Comments: Comprehensive documentation has been provided. Still if a user has any difficulty, he/she can reach out to us using our email address

Observations: Does the website and documentation describe what support, if any, you provide to users and developers?
Does the project have an e-mail address or forum that is solely for supporting users?
Are e-mails to it's support e-mail address received by more than one person?
Does this project have a ticketing system to manage bug reports and feature requests?
Comments: It uses github Issue and Pull Requests

Observations: Is the project's ticketing system publicly visible to your users, so they can view bug reports and feature requests?
Software's Maintance
Is the software’s architecture and design modular?
Does the software use an accepted coding standard or convention?
Open standards in software
Does your software allow data to be imported and exported using open data formats?* e.g. GIF, SVG, HTML, XML, tar, zip, CSV, JSON, NetCDF, or domain specific ones
Does your software allow communications using open communications protocols?*e.g. HTTP, FTP, XMPP, SOAP over HTTP, or domain-specific ones
Software's Cross-Compability

Is the software cross-platform compatible?* e.g. does it run under two or more of Windows, Unix/Linux and Mac OS X, or can be used from within two or more of Internet Explorer, Chrome, Firefox and Safari?
Comments: Extension can be run on any OS

Observations: Software's accessibility
Does the software adhere to appropriate accessibility conventions or standards?
Does the documentation adhere to appropriate accessibility conventions or standards?
Software's Realising Cycle
Is the source code stored in a repository under revision control?
Is each source code release a snapshot of the repository?
Are releases tagged in the repository?
Is there a branch of the repository that is always stable? (i.e. tests always pass, code always builds successfully)
Do the sofware back-up it's repository?
Software's Installation and Build
Do it provide publicly-available instructions for building the software from the source code?

Can it build, or package, the software using an automated tool?* e.g. Make (https://www.gnu.org/software/make/), ANT (http://ant.apache.org/), Maven (https://maven.apache.org/), CMake (https://cmake.org/), Python setuptools (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/setuptools), or R package tools (https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-devel/R-exts.html)
Do it provide publicly-available instructions for deploying the software?
Does the documentation list all third-party dependencies?
Does the documentation list the version number for all third-party dependencies?
Does the software list the web address, and licences for all third-party dependencies and say whether the dependencies are mandatory or optional?

Can it download dependencies using a dependency management tool or package manager?* e.g. Ivy (http://ant.apache.org/ivy/), Maven (https://maven.apache.org/), Python pip (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/pip) or setuptools (https://pypi.python.org/pypi/setuptools), PHP Composer (https://getcomposer.org/), Ruby gems (https://rubygems.org), or R PackRat (https://rstudio.github.io/packrat/)
Do it have tests that can be run after the software has been built or deployed to show whether the build or deployment has been successful?
Software's Testing
Do it have an automated test suite for the software?
Do it have a framework to periodically (e.g. nightly) run the tests on the latest version of the source code?
Do it use continuous integration, automatically running tests whenever changes are made to the source code?
Comments: No GitHub Actions are present for the same

Observations: Are the test results publicly visible?
Are all manually-run tests documented?
